Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Ah, 'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes,' a rollercoaster that's more like a kiddie ride at a local fair. Buckle up, folks - we're in for a lukewarm journey.Coriolanus Snow's transformation is like watching a caterpillar attempt ballet - ambitious but fundamentally awkward. Tom Blyth and Viola Davis give stellar performances, though it feels a bit like winning an Oscar for a school play. And that brief love story? It's the spice equivalent of saltine crackers - a bit bland.Now, the characters. Picture a group of friends you wouldn't invite to your birthday party. That's them. More background and growth? Apparently, that's too much to ask. The pacing is so off; I thought I accidentally switched to 'Hunger Games: The Slow Motion Edition.' Trim it? More like perform a cinematic exorcism.Rachel Zegler's acting is stiffer than a frozen baguette, and the singing scenes? It's like they handed out microphones at a karaoke night for tone-deaf cats. The connection to the original Hunger Games series is shakier than my Wi-Fi during a storm.'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' has its moments, like finding a semi-interesting receipt in your wallet - mildly intriguing, but hardly a jackpot. If they iron out these wrinkles, maybe the next chapters will be less like a kiddie ride and more like a rollercoaster with actual loops. Fingers crossed for an upgrade, but hey, miracles happen, right?

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: You can find a review on this everywhere else I will skip to what I felt could have been so interesting and was missed out on.This story has always had deep themes around class warfare, dystopian government, mankind's ability to separate people and make Others Inhuman and able to be treated as cattle. So I think one big missed opportunity is with the plot around the Mentor Program and Corio Snow. Something that has always stuck with me are the servant master relationships we hear about during the American Slavery period. Famously, Thomas Jefferson had a very romantic time with one of his slaves. There should have been more about Lucy Gray, what does she really feel, does she feel grateful? Do they really fall in love or is she playing him? Yes there is that in the beginning but the movie never has the guts to say, these people are in a deep love for each other even though its a sick relationship with an extreme power imbalance. Perhaps they could show her having the power over a foolish Snow. She gets him to rig the games for her and yet has a soft spot for him by the end. Snow could be scandalized by being shown addicted to his "lesser human" girlfriend and therefore his cheating allegations and exile would impact him because he would be deeply grieving feeling that he would never see Lucy again. Lots of ways they could go with this.Also there is just not enough done with the 1960s TV premise. What if this was the first Games in Color? People in The Capital would see the red blood of kids for the first time, would that make a difference on how Panem sees the kids? So many characters could bring you a deep feeling through their eyes of seeing all this awful trauma.How Snow relates to the people on District 12 how it made him change The Hunger Games in how he did how it made him see the people of Panem as human beings and yet how he rationalized seeing himself as worthy of dominating and controlling them at the end, is stuff that can take the viewers on a ride of terror and imagination.The premise, theme, storyline and dialogues of this movie in the right hands are Oscar winning. Too bad they failed on most execution. Another movie that could be life changing wasted in the Hollywood machine. At least it was watchable and had some cool world building so 5/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Having seen, but never been a particularly big fan of "The Hunger Games" movies, I almost didn't go and see his prequel. But it worked out timewise, and I really want to make a concerted effort to see more films at the cinema this year, so I decided to risk it. I was surprisingly impressed with how complex the descent of Snow was handled.With his family near destitute, Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) is banking on graduating from the academy with the prestigious Plinth Prize, which would solve his families' problems. However, at the last moment he, and the rest of this class, are tasked with a final assignment. They each have to mentor a competitor in this years Hunger Games, the 10th annual event, the future of which is in doubt as people have stopped watching. Snow is placed with Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler) a musical performer from district 12, who is charismatic and personable, but lacking the heart for the violence to come.So, I remembered enough to know that Snow would go on to be the President and antagonist of the later films, so I knew roughly where we were heading. I was surprised at how slowly paced and ... justifiable even ... the stages of his compromised heel turn were. I understand he's more of a monster from the beginning in the book and some people criticised this adaptation for that, but this has to be a more interesting way to go, and Tom Blyth does a good job of keeping things balanced. I liked a lot of the performances, with Viola Davis going big as the current games organiser and Peter Dinklage in a role that becomes more sympathetic as the films goes on.I don't think I'd argue against the film's other criticism though, that's it's long. I did feel its two and half hour run time. With the Hunger Games themselves competed around the halfway point in the film. I'd also say we could have done with a little more differentiation between the other competitors as I often wasn't sure who was who.I don't want to go overboard and over praise a film which does have some issues, but given I had almost no expectation going on, that it was a surprisingly complex and accomplished film, was a nice surprise.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The major beats of the book plot play out more or less exactly as written here in the movie. It falls flat because the author decided this story required "adult pathos" to justify its existence, and, most unfortunately, writes that pathos like a 12 year old making their first big foray into Wattpad. Other than a few vaguely satisfying beats in the (very short) Games sequence, there's nothing here but incredibly amateurish melodrama, and that's all true-to-text.All the best parts of the political intrigue and action/adventure that make the first trilogy so engaging are completely absent, or present only as cameo-style, utterly embarrassing call-backs to those 10-year-old stories that actually interested you. The romance was the worst part of the original series, but here you're begging for it because if it's not the current on-screen focus then you're probably watching a bizarre musical theater kid wet dream where Everybody Has To Stop And Be Impressed By Your Heartfelt Singing That Happens To Be Precisely Suited To The Collective Emotional Moment And Isn't That So Cool. There are literally five or six EXTENDED musical sequences that serve absolutely no plot function, but are wielded by the author like plot points nonetheless, because she's got nothing else to offer while moving the story forward.This flick may not actually be 525,600 minutes long but you could sure fool me by the end. Hard pass.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" falls short of the high expectations set by its predecessors. Despite its attempt to delve into the origin story of President Snow, the film struggles to captivate audiences. The pacing is uneven, with long stretches of exposition that lack the gripping tension characteristic of the franchise.The choice to center the narrative around a young Snow feels misguided. While exploring the evolution of a villain can be intriguing, the execution here feels forced and fails to humanize the character. Donald Sutherland's charismatic portrayal in the earlier films is sorely missed, leaving a void that the new lead fails to fill convincingly.The film's production design is commendable, successfully recreating the dystopian world of Panem. However, the visual elements alone cannot compensate for the weak character development and a lackluster script. The absence of a strong female protagonist akin to Katniss Everdeen is particularly noticeable, depriving the story of the resilience and depth that defined the previous installments.Furthermore, the film's attempt to provide social commentary on privilege and power lacks subtlety, coming across as heavy-handed and didactic. The subtleties that made the original trilogy thought-provoking are sacrificed for a more straightforward narrative, diminishing the intellectual engagement that characterized earlier films.Despite a few redeeming moments, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" ultimately fails to capture the essence of its predecessors. Fans of the franchise may find it disappointing, as it struggles to live up to the legacy established by the original trilogy. While the film has its merits, it pales in comparison to the thought-provoking and emotionally resonant storytelling that made "The Hunger Games" a cultural phenomenon.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I had very few expectations going into this movie, in my opinion a Hunger Games prequel sounded like a great premise. But a few things were difficult to watch. Primarily that Lucy Gray was not the protagonist this series deserved. From a wavering southern bell accent (which vacillated wildly) to the near musical territory the movie wandered into, this HG prequel felt like a very long made for premium streaming exclusive. Redemption comes from Tom Blythe, who was phenomenal, but the third act dragged heavily and I found myself asking why he looked like Eminem in District 12. The odd love story between Snow and Gray wasn't helped by the sort of Gypsy bard rebel played by Rachel Zegler.The movie had its moments but I was personally removed from the story every time Zegler had a different accent or used some southern turn of phrase. To me it just fell flat but made canonical sense in what really happened to Snow that sent him down his capital path.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Another movie in the same storyline as the first two. But in contrast, it failed to deliver the same interest. A producer trying to prolong the interest and liking of the first two movies. But that is about as far as it goes. No " Games of Thrones" here, just simple viewing for 5 to 15 year olds. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: As a long-time fan of the Hunger Games franchise, I approached the new "Hunger Games" with a blend of excitement and caution. Unfortunately, my caution was warranted. The film, from start to finish, felt like a tedious journey through a poorly constructed narrative.First and foremost, the characters in this iteration lacked depth and credibility. Their motivations were unclear, and their actions often felt random, contributing to a disjointed storyline. It was as if the script was generated by an AI like ChatGPT, lacking the human touch that usually brings characters to life.The overall quality of the film was underwhelming. From the CGI effects to the set design, everything seemed to be done with minimal effort and creativity. The dialogues were particularly disappointing, often bordering on nonsensical, which further detached me from the story.Moreover, the plot itself was a letdown. It neither honored the original Hunger Games spirit nor offered anything new or exciting. It was as if the producers simply relied on the franchise's name to carry the movie, without putting in the necessary work to make it stand out.In conclusion, Hunger Games is a forgettable addition to the franchise. It's a stark reminder that not all sequels or spin-offs live up to their names. For future projects, I hope more attention is given to developing engaging characters and a compelling narrative, the very elements that made the original Hunger Games so captivating.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The movie was pretty good overall - and much better than any expectations for a prequel given the recent history of movie franchises trying to milk more money out of a successful trilogy. The cast is well-done and the story overall isn't like Hunger Games 2 where it was just more or less a replay of Hunger Games 1. I like how the background is constructed in a way that gives information without going through endless boring plots and side plots of characters that aren't memorable.I would have given it a 9/10 (tying my rating for the original) if the ending was better linked to the first Hunger Games. While, a lot is implied by how the movie ends. I would have liked more linkage on Snow's health issues in the Mockingjay movies where he had poisoned himself in order to poison and kill all his enemies. Whether it be by the way he did in this movie or some other method, there should have been more hints that he was willing to hurt himself to wipe out all his enemies. Unless they are planning to make a sequel to the prequel, I think they could have added about 5 minutes of screen time to explain how exactly he became President Snow.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
The first Hunger Games with Jennifer Lawrence was a very good film. It was fresh and new and Katniss Everdeen was a great movie character.A side character in that trilogy ( 4 films ) was President Snow, this film is a prequel to the original films showing him in his youth before his rise to power.The film is split into 3 parts.Part 1 - is an introduction to Snow and his friends/fellow students and also the tributes of the 10th hunger games.Part 2 - is the 10th Hunger games
Part 3 - is how Snow starts his journey to becoming the looming dictator he becomes in the OT.This is why the film really fails to deliver.Part 1 is lacking in development and introduces way to many characters although the focus here is Snow and Lucy Gray Baird, her first name is ' Lucy Gray ' not just Lucy.Played by Rachel Zegler she is the antipathy of Katniss, her strengths are singing and charm centred around an aloof but colourful character.Of course Snow is mesmerised.Part 2 centres around the 10th Hunger games where viewing figures and interest have been waning to the point this could be the last. Thats right the central part of this show is just how lacklustre the Hunger Games have become. A fairly small old building is the arena for this and yes its dull and boring, this makes what should be a beautiful climax, just seem lifeless.Part 3 is a long winded prologue covering punishment for Snow his ostracism from the capitol and then his return... by this point however you may have stopped caring.Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage appear fleetingly, Viola steals the limelight every time. Tom Blyth is good as Snow, a snakey but transient young man. Zegler uses her singing talents well but is more of a romantic supporting interest than a winning hero.Dinklage I felt was underused as were the majority of the rest of the cast.Overall there is an interesting story there but it wasn't told in an interesting way and I can't think of any really good or stand out re watchable moments. It was very studio set/green screen throughout and it felt like there was little chemistry between the actors.A 5 or 6 out of 10 for me.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is by far one of the best entries in The Hunger Games franchise! A perfect adaptation of the novel, it expands on its dark dystopian world with rich costumes, stunning art direction, an epic score, and a sense of scale and scope that's fitting for this prequel about the rise of President Snow. And it's so much richer than dystopian young adult adaptations are usually ever allowed to be! I'm struggling to remember the last time a prequel was this much better and more interesting than the rest of its franchise. I love the nuanced, darker story that is more of a character study than anything which was so well executed by returning director Francis Lawrence in this colder prequel. He brought new life to the franchise with his masterful take on Catching Fire, and did it once again with The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, delivering a darker, more sinister version of the Games through Snow's perspective that is ten times better than it has any right to be.Significantly more intimate and grounded than the previous Hunger Games movies (despite being longer than any of them and responsible for seeding all of their lore), The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is the rare prequel that manages to stand on its own two feet and still feel taller than the other stories it's ultimately meant to support.But the real star is the cast. They crush it. Rachel Zegler truly shines and is super captivating in this. If you thought she was good in West Side Story, just wait until you see her here! Plus she gets to show off her incredible singing skills multiple times! I really loved her here, she truly is a star on the rise. Her character Lucy Gray is very different from Katniss, (Katniss was a fighter forced to perform, Lucy Gray is a performer forced to fight) and the tense, twisty dynamics between Lucy and Tom Blyth's Coriolanus are a treat to watch. Tom Blyth is a standout, selling Snow's moral ambiguity/decay with such a subtle, nuanced, and gifted performance. Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage are powerhouses and wildly compelling, as they usually are. Davis' character in particular is so devious, and it's so marvelous to watch. Plus this film has one of the 3 best Jason Schwartzman performances of the year - he's hilarious in this!With high stakes, solid action, and killer performances, The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a thrilling return to Panem, assisted by some excellent production design and the return of memorable motifs/themes in the musical score. I love that so many people who worked on the original films came back for this one, really helping to make it all feel cohesive with the other films (especially thanks to James Newton Howard's excellent score)! This is purely grand, epic storytelling. It's long for sure, but doesn't drag. It works well by doing something fairly different from the first series, taking on a unique story structure that most studios would try to separate into a two-part movie. But I'm so glad they didn't split this up, and it still came out as such a faithful adaptation of Suzanne Collins' novel. I loved this film! My sister, who doesn't love movies, loved this film (said it's the longest she's ever been compelled by a movie)! It's genuinely a very fair candidate for the best film in The Hunger Games franchise, either as good as or better than Catching Fire! The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a magnificent film that not only excels in its own right, but also enriches the original franchise that is it now a part of. If you loved The Hunger Games, you can't miss this!It's the things we love most that destroy us.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The latest installment in the Hunger Games saga is a visual feast that captivates from start to finish. The aesthetics of the movie are nothing short of breathtaking, with meticulous attention to detail evident in both the costumes and architecture. The effects used throughout the film contribute to its overall immersive experience, bringing to life the dystopian world of Panem in a way that feels both futuristic and hauntingly plausible.One of the standout aspects of the movie is the introduction of Olivia and Rodrigo's song, adding a contemporary touch to the film's soundtrack. The incorporation of modern elements seamlessly blends with the dystopian setting, creating a unique and memorable atmosphere.The acting in the movie is stellar, with each cast member delivering a compelling performance. The casting choices are spot-on, bringing characters to life with authenticity and depth. The story itself serves as a captivating exploration of the origins of the Hunger Games and why the people of Panem tune in to watch these brutal competitions. It sheds light on the motivations and decisions that set the stage for the future tribulations faced by the districts.However, the narrative takes an unexpected turn with Lucy Gray's victory and the subsequent government response. While the film excels in portraying the evolution of President Snow, the transformation of another key character, Coryo, felt sudden and somewhat perplexing. The ambiguity surrounding his shift to evil leaves viewers questioning the overall message of the movie.The ending, unfortunately, left some viewers scratching their heads. The abruptness of Coryo's descent into darkness felt somewhat random, especially considering the film's focus on the gradual corruption of President Snow. The climax raises questions about the broader message, as it seems to suggest that achieving goals involves sacrificing morality and resorting to extreme measures.Despite these reservations, the movie provides an engaging and entertaining experience. The captivating storyline, impressive visuals, and strong performances make it a worthy addition to the Hunger Games universe. The decision to cast an attractive actor as the villain adds an interesting layer, making it challenging for viewers to completely despise the character. Nevertheless, the abrupt narrative shift in the concluding moments may leave some fans feeling a bit unsatisfied, longing for a more coherent resolution to the story of Panem's descent into darkness.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Rachel Zegler is a great singer but the whole singing parts just felt weird and forced. I was waiting for the movie to turn into a musical. Throughout the movie Lucy Gray has a guardian angel around her, giving her Spider-Man reflexes so she doesn't even have to fight. I call it Avoidant Mary Sue. Of course she doesn't have any flaws, just a kind person who does everything from the good of her heart. Someone you would never trust if you met her in real life, unless you're naive and inexperienced. In short, very badly written. The characters romance comes out of nowhere and moves so fast it felt like a comedic relief. The relationships between characters also abruptly change without any explanation whatsoever, turning them against each other. This is shown in Snow's character, the main villain in the series, who suddenly changes into a murdering psychopath.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Does this film fit cohesively within the Hunger Games franchise? Absolutely. The tone of this film is nearly identical to the rest; with its half-baked sets embodied by CGI, warm tones to portray the deceiving virtues of the Capital contrasted by cold tones to showcase the depleted nature of the districts, and the solo buildup of a character who expresses heroic mentalities. The problem that director Francis Lawrence runs into is trying to mimic Coriolanus Snow's journey with the story of Katniss Everdeen. The first 65% of the film is truly entertaining, however the predetermined outcome of this character is exposed by a choppy transition in the story arc in order to blend this film organically within the franchise. Tom Blyth gives a credible performance that is heightened by the fact that he's shown in 95% of the film, whereas Rachel Zegler pioneers the innovative approach of making this adaptation a musical. Similar to large IP franchises such as Marvel, DC, or Star Wars, there's an equal amount of moments to criticize as there are to enjoy, and I'm perfectly fine with that.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I saw The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes, starring Tom Blyth-Billy the Kid_tv, Robin Hood_2010; Rachel Zegler-Shazam! Fury of the Gods, West Side Story_2021; Viola Davis-The Woman King, Law Abiding Citizen and Peter Dinklage-Cyrano, Game of Thrones_tv.This is the origin story of Coriolanus Snow-Donald Sutherland's character in the original movies-so it is a prequel that covers how he came into power. Tom plays Coriolanus, a student rising in the ranks in the Capital. Viola is the President of Panem, with Peter as her next in command. The 10th annual Hunger Games are starting a new season and Tom has Rachel as his volunteer-the Capital calls them tributes. Tom is her mentor in the games but begins to have feelings for Rachel and wants her to actually win, which is not what Viola wants, so they tend to butt heads over protocol. FYI: In case you are wondering about the sub title in the name, Rachel likes to sing-hence the nickname Songbird-and Viola has a 20 foot tank of snakes that she has been experimenting with and uses them on occasions, when necessary. It's a little slow in parts but overall, it's a good origin story.It's rated PG-13 for violence and disturbing material and has a running time of 2 hours & 37 minutes.I would probably buy it on DVD.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Unlike so many movies of late, I found this Hunger Games prequel to be engaging, immersive, yet quite disturbing. I had not read the book deliberately, because I wanted to experience the film in its own right, rather than how faithfully it reproduced a written work. Regardless, it effectively chronicles the pivotal events in the nascent corruption of Coriolanus Snow.The horror of the actual Games is far more primitive, gritty and raw than before... much more like Thunderdome from the Mad Max franchise: "Get to the weapons. Use them any way you can. I know you won't break the rules. There aren't any." The sickness of this society is encapsulated by the fact that one of the Tributes is a young girl who appears to have Down's Syndrome. Try to wrap your head around that idea...I found the characters to be sufficiently developed for the purposes of the film's narrative. Folk music is interwoven into the movie, perfectly to effect: one of the main protagonists is a folk singer who expresses her emotions and defiance through song.The "look and feel" of this era of Panem is brilliant: a bizarrely familiar reimagining of mid-century modern motifs grotesquely blended with elements of the totalitarian architecture of the Third Reich. For those who know the actual photographic record of the latter, you will see numerous things in this film which echo that visual vocabulary, and not simply the sets.I'd recommend seeing this film: given the times we live in, it certainly is a thought-provoking journey.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is by no means a bad movie. It is entertaining, engaging, and has flashes of brilliance. The Hunger Games prequel also is an adaptation of a young adult novel--and such theme focuses may make or break your enjoyment of it.For a very basic overview, "Songbirds & Snakes" focuses on Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth), the individual who will ultimately become the Donald Sutherland-played villain of the originals. Mentoring District 12's Lucy Gray (Rachel Zegler) in a very early Hunger Games iteration, Snow falls for her (or is that the other way around?) and the two form an unlikely pairing that will ultimately lead both of them in very different directions.As I mentioned, there were parts of this film that I truly did enjoy. In some ways, it is a star vehicle for Zegler, whose singing talents are truly special. Seeing such an early iteration of the Hunger Games competition is of course interesting, and there are a number of "easter eggs" for fans of the original films to smile at.However, I will argue that "Songbirds & Snakes" fails at its primary mission: to show the trajectory of Coriolanus Snow from well-meaning Panem student to the sneering Sutherland villain. The strange thing is, the film doesn't outrightly fail at this task--all (or at least most of) the steps are indeed present. But they are handled with a very YA sensibility befitting the novels they are based on. In other words, the themes and arcs of this movie are best invested by a tween, teen, or younger audience, I think. Some of the material is very much "on the nose", while at other times it comes off as a bit lacking in true follow-through of the Snow character mission other than "well, we know he's going to become the big baddie, so...".Granted, the original Hunger Games set largely has those YA approaches baked into it too, but the inclusion of Jennifer Lawrence's super-serious Katniss was a tonic (at least for me). As good as Zegler is as an entertainer, she is not in the Lawrence acting category (at least not yet).Perhaps others will not have as much of a "sophistication" problem with "Songbirds & Snakes" as I did. But other than never being bored, the flick failed to draw me into its key tenets of existence because I felt it was constantly shooting for only the approval of a much younger audience than I.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I just don't feel like it did anything to meaningfully justify its own existence. It's well-made, that's for certain, and the actors are trying extremely hard to believe in the world the filmmakers have put them in. But it just smells so...Hollywood. DOA. It's like looking at a corpse of a Hunger Games movie. Clearly, it's going to make a zillion dollars, especially internationally (I saw it in a semi-packed theater in Madrid). It's almost like what Disney is doing to Marvel -- inventing pre- and back-stories that actually don't need to exist because they add nothing to the canon, nor do they change the way you see the other movies. No additive comprehension. The Games themselves were much, much too short, and they solved the problem of the games themselves in a deus ex machina way that was deeply unsatisfying. I'm super impressed with Rachel Zegler, because she clearly is a talented musician who learned probably 10 different songs for this movie...but in the end, the whole thing feels like a borderline musical meant to appease an imagined audience consisting mostly of teenagers. In other words? Weirdly gimmicky. I found the whole thing boring, and kind of stale. Give it a pass. You'll be fine.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: More of a political thriller than an action adventure, the story follows the creator of the new Hunger Games in three distinct parts. Good use of imagery and foreshadowing as it reuses the main themes from the original stories but with a fresh view. The story is good if a bit simplified and obvious at times, but it was enjoyable throughout due to the great acting from the main cast, the cracking country ballads and the use of contrast from the grand to the dilapidated in the scenery and settings. The Games themselves weren't as shocking or thrilling as they could have been, but were still entertaining to watch and the run-down nature of the arena fitted well within the post-war recovery setting.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This film has an interesting look and design. It relly feels like the past of this world where they haven't yet perfected the devious Hunger Games. But sooo much on-the-nose dialogue where characters only talk about the things they've done, in part, makes this a terrible script. And what is the story here, star-crossed lovers or rags-to-riches rise of a fascist dictator? The director doesn't know, so why should we care? Finally, if the plot is the latter, then it's really hard to care about the rise of a evil character. And Lucy Grey isn't that much better because she makes many questionable choices and not the ones she thinks are bad. Skip this film and rewatch the OG, which is almost a flawless script and film.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'll start off by saying I've never read the books, and nor should I have to! It's a film after all.The first 1/3 of the movie starts off really well. We're instantly transported into the world, we learn about and connect with our main character, and the plot is set up, ready to go, potentially greatness awaits.Unfortunately, when the actual games starts, the writing just goes downhill, where in the cinema I actually shook my head with disappointment several times. The overall quality does actually pick up around 2/3, but out ending then crashing down to an overall 6/10.The writing, like a lot of tv and cinema these days, just let's it down. Moments that could be poignant become laughable, and I also feel (despite its long run time) certain parts, particularly connecting with anyone but our protagonist, we're very rushed.Lastly, Rachel Ziegler just isn't a very good actor. Almost all of her lines are delivered in exactly the same way, which is a shame as our lead I actually thought did a really good job. Worth seeing, but not watching again.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This movie was so disappointing. It was nothing like the Book and had so many holes in the plot line. It felt so rushed. I can't stand Rachel Ziegler as lucy gray. She's just so harsh and stiff with the mannerisms and it feels very forced in the acting. I really didn't enjoy the singing in the movie either. I wish they touched more on Coriolanus and Sejanus' relationship. I didn't like the casting and felt the cast didnt fit the roles in the book. I wish it was more true to the book. The characters just felt empty and like nothing was behind them. I did however really like Tom bylth as Coriolanus he was the perfect snow.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'd love to provide you with a detailed review of "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes."Suzanne Collins' return to the Hunger Games universe with "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" was highly anticipated, promising a prequel that would delve into the origins of the tyrannical President Snow and the early days of the Hunger Games. Set decades before Katniss Everdeen's time, this novel takes us back to the core of Panem's history, offering a deeper understanding of the world we came to know in the original trilogy.The story introduces us to a young Coriolanus Snow, whose life and aspirations are dramatically altered when he is assigned to mentor the tribute from District 12, Lucy Gray Baird, in the 10th Hunger Games. Snow's character development is central to this narrative, as we witness his moral compass and ambitions shape under the weight of societal expectations and personal choices.Collins skillfully paints a bleak and captivating picture of the Capitol, detailing its opulence and disparity from the districts. The grim reality of life outside the Capitol is portrayed vividly, showcasing the struggle for survival and the bleak circumstances faced by the oppressed districts. The author succeeds in creating a palpable sense of tension and unease, establishing the foundation for the totalitarian regime familiar to readers of the original series.The introduction of Lucy Gray Baird, a charismatic and enigmatic tribute, adds depth and intrigue to the storyline. Her mysterious nature and captivating performances on stage during the Games provide a compelling contrast to Snow's calculated demeanor. The dynamic between Snow and Lucy Gray drives much of the novel, presenting a complex interplay of manipulation, loyalty, and survival instincts.One of the strengths of this prequel is its exploration of the moral gray areas within the characters. It presents a thought-provoking examination of the circumstances that can shape a person's choices and values, blurring the lines between right and wrong. Through Snow's internal conflicts and rationalizations, Collins challenges readers to consider the nature of power, privilege, and the consequences of one's actions.However, despite its intriguing premise and character study, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" has been met with mixed reactions. Some readers found it challenging to empathize with a young President Snow, while others appreciated the nuanced portrayal of a character who eventually becomes the series' primary antagonist. The pacing of the novel has also been a point of contention, with moments that feel drawn out juxtaposed with bursts of intense action.Additionally, while the book offers insights into the creation of the Hunger Games and the Capitol's early days, it might not satisfy those expecting the same adrenaline-fueled narrative as the original trilogy. The absence of the rebellion's fervor and the societal critique present in the previous books could leave some Hunger Games enthusiasts wanting more.In conclusion, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a daring exploration of the Hunger Games universe, providing a deeper understanding of President Snow's character and the origins of the Games. Collins' narrative choices and her ability to humanize a character traditionally viewed as a villain contribute to a thought-provoking read. However, its departure from the familiar tone of the original series and its divisive portrayal of a young Snow might not resonate with all fans. It's a book that provokes discussion and offers a new perspective on the complexities of human nature and power.

Reviewer_Content: Inconsistent acting varying from melodramatic to good to inadequate.Soundtrack inconsistent varying from excellent to pathetic including ruining an excellent son (hanging tree).Story very contrived and didn't make sense in some places.The capital scenes did not meet expectations and seemed very budget dependent. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: First off- the initially mixed reviews on this shock me. I am admittedly a large fan of the first four movies, which is why I was equally as excited and scared to see this film. It did not disappoint. Excellent plot throughout, and it did an amazing job translating the book into a movie. If there was anything negative to say it would be I wanted a little more backstory, but I still thought every character was great and well acted. From start to finish it doesn't have any weak moments, and each scene feels like it has a purpose. This installment connects well with the other four movies, and honestly I just hope we might get a another at some point in the future.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Went to see this movie with my wife, and one of our best friends. The movie was well designed, and casted. Acting was 10/10. However, the plot was horrible. This was not "villain origin" this was "writer wrote a perfect love story and decided he wanted the main character to be evil out of NO-WHERE". I still don't understand the ending at all. Snow didn't seem to lose his mind. He just seemed to be turned into a being of pure evil in the last 10-15 minutes of this USELESS 2.5 HOUR MOVIE. I wish I had not wasted the time on it. It gave no meaning to the story line. I'm not sure what the intention, or goal was- with the creation of this movie. Thoroughly disappointed.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'm not a Hunger Games fan, but this installment fell short for me, earning only two stars. As a newcomer to The Hunger Games movies, I found this prequel to be unnecessarily violent. Despite being rated PG-13, it showcased more violence, bloodshed, and killing compared to several R-rated movies I've seen, raising concerns about its appropriateness.The movie was not only gruesome and brutal but also left an uncomfortable impression. The atmosphere depicted a world where everyone turns on each other, devoid of characters to genuinely root for. This lack of relatable protagonists made the entire experience cringe-worthy and depressing.While I acknowledge that the themes align with the book series, the level of discomfort surpassed my expectations. Exiting the theater, my friends and I shared a collective feeling of unease. If the subsequent movies continue to portray such intense violence and the bleak depiction of humanity turning on itself, I may choose to skip them altogether.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I didn't give myself over to Songbirds & Snakes immediately. The movie certainly had my attention and I think the opening was very strong in establishing Coriolanus as a complicated protagonist and setting him down his path to both his triumph and later his destruction. It took me a while to warm up to Lucy Gray, she was too feisty and too finely geared to make her likeable. But her willingness to trust Snow instead of just being whiny and mistrustful and her not too squeaky clean sense of morality wore me down. Her character picks up steam after the games are done and by the end, I was rooting for her. My biggest problem with the original series was how selfish and petulant Katniss could be and Songbirds & Snakes flips the formula by asking us to root for the villain. One of my friends suggested a House of Cards style show just showing Snow's rise to power and S&S showed the potential and promise that kind of project.I hadn't seen either Tom Blyth previously but to follow Donald Sutherland in this role couldn't have been easy. I was quite impressed with his commanding presence and how well he captured Snow's charm and conversely his ruthlessness. He definitely brought some humanity to the character and he conveys slow descent well. Rachel has a ton of energy as Lucy Gray and she's good at being vulnerable in the beginning and being coy & mysterious near the end. Viola Davis, Peter Dinklage and Jason Schwartzman are the heavy hitters in the supporting cast and I enjoyed them all. Viola comes on strong at the start (could the obviously evil character turn out to be evil?) but her performance fits and Dr. Gaul transforms into a formidable enemy by the end.I also want to congratulate this movie for putting more of a focus on the animosity between the Capitol and the Districts. There's a lot more anger and venom between the two sides and the bitterness adds to the stakes. They also do a good job of showing how disorganized the games could be in their beginning cycles. This version of the Hunger Games is much less glamorous, the tributes are barely suitable, the mentors are only in it for themselves and the citizens of the Capitol barely care. It adds to the bleakness of the festivities and how they would eventual fuel another rebellion which is important in where the story will eventually finish with the Katniss saga.I did have some problems with this movie, but they were mostly minor. Songbirds & Snakes relies on some plot contrivances and the film can't help but being a little precious when it's winking at elements from the original trilogy. This is something that isn't unique to Songbirds & Snakes but wouldn't it be nice if it could have been avoided? But the easiest and most obvious problem is that S&S feels a little overproduced. It's been pruned and tweaked for maximum power several times over and it robs it of some of it's spontaneity. I still really enjoyed it but I couldn't help but feel like I was being manipulated a little bit.I really didn't expect much going into this movie. I saw the original trilogy and read the books but I considered The Hunger Games finished and I moved on. I was blown away by how intricately packed and well made this prequel was. Judging by the other user reviews, I might in the minority but Songbirds & Snakes builds on the mythology while staying true to the spirit, the film shapes Coriolanus Snow into a layered and engaging character/villain and reignites the fire for this universe. I'm somewhere between an 8.5-9/10 but I'd wholly recommend this and unless you're extremely attached to the original trilogy, I'd be surprised if you walk away from the theatre without something to discuss or a new appreciation for this franchise. To Suzanne Collins, Francis Lawrence and the creative team, Bravo!

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: 3 out of 5 stars.The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is a fair dystopian action film that is a prequel to the Hunger Game series. Showing the earlier years of Coriolanus Snow who was the president in the previous films. And his attribute Lucy Gray which she was picked for the tenth Hunger Games.The film follows Snow as he sees society in the dystopian world struggling to live. While Lucy Grays perspective she is fighting for survival. The plot is good. The first hour or so has Lucy going through the Hunger Games and surviving. While last hour follows Snow going through the districts as a soldier looking for Lucy. And dealing with a rebellion.It has a great cast ensemble. Rachel Zegler performance stole the show. The script and direction does feel overlong which has a lot of boring and slow moments. The action sequences is decent and forgettable. May not be the best film in the series. It is not the worst.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Hunger Games: Ballad of songbirds and snakes" (2023) not only the title is too long, the movie also was. I liked the character development in the beginning but as the movie went on I started to dislike every single one of them.The only nice thing I can say about this movie is that it was nice learning about the past of the Hunger Games universe. Not that I was a good past in any way shape or form.This movie on it's own though, if we don't look at the other Hunger Games movies, does not do good. The only reason why it is an okay movie is because of it's prequels and sequels. This movie as an independent movie was not good.Casting was poorly done and so was the acting. Hearing Peter Dinklage's character try to speak with an American accent was horrible, it was so bad.Other than that i can only say i enjoyed some scenery shots, it was aesthetically well done and beautiful at moments.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Film felt ungrounded and there was no sense of universe or tone being created the way the previous Hunger Games films had done, including the characters. It seemed that the main character broke out into song at every opportunity and the movie lacked some grit. We weren't ever introduced to who the characters were, which left us with no one to root for.Moments that were meant to be heartfelt sometimes fell flat, leaving us a bit uncomfortable. No clear sense of urgency or stakes to a majority of the movie, other than Viola Davis and Snow's Friend. I understand what was the vision but it wasn't clearly or artistically communicated.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Having being a massive Harry Potter fan i didn't watch the first Hunger games film as it came out a year after the ending of Harry Potter so wasn't really into films for 2 years after, 2013 came around and i was intrigued by the Global recognition The first Hunger Games was getting which just happened to be the year the 2nd film was due for release,the story line was gripping and Catniss was just cast so perfectly, Jennifer Lawrence was stunning and portrayed the character like it was reality. All four films every single cast member was brilliant in there own right.Fast forward to this prequel and to put it bluntly it's a shambles, The cast is just terrible.No cohesion between anyone in any scene, they seem to build a character and then you dont see them for an hour if not ever again in the film.Flashback to the first films and Jennifer Lawrence can't really sing but is subtle in her singing that it seems natural she knows she can't sing so tones it down to something bearable. Now Rachel Zegler on the other hand thinks she can sing and it's just terrible every scene in which she sings a song is unbearable, plus she isn't a great actress at all, I just see it as they have rode the curtails of a major movie which was made what it is by great actors and actresses to promote up and coming actors and actresses.Snows character in this film didn't make any sense, having seen him magnificently portrayed by Donald Sutherland to seeing how he is portrayed in this film is just mind boggling, maybe its because Donald is a brilliant actor who knows.The film is supposed to be about the games and for me wasn't enough scenes actually about the games.Overall I would say if this was the very first Hunger Games film in the franchise then they wouldn't of managed to make another 3 movies or a prequel movie after it.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes plunges us into a vintage Panem and i'll admit, i'd love to see more stories in this world. The production of this movie is really brilliant; costumes, set design and the old school aesthetic all are perfect.Tom Blyth is the heart of this movie and he does a really good job with what he's given (Rachel Zegler also has an amazing voice). My issue with the characters in this movie is that we aren't given enough time for their character arcs to really hit home and to care enough about them to understand their motivations.It all wraps up far too suddenly in the third act and here lies the issue of pacing in the film. It's quite uneven, spending too long on some parts and not enough on others. It works for the most part but some areas begin to drag.Overall i had a fun time with this but was left a bit disappointed. Snow's backstory is great but not as good as it should have been.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Hungers game being the franchise that it is and ending the way it did, this film was not needed. We had a perfect ending to the franchise and this one just feels out of place. Don't get me wrong it was a good film with a rough ending, but the action in this film was lacking, we had some good moments in this film but we also had some tough moments too, and some of the kills in this film feel cheap. Hunger games being the big franchise that it is, the types of kills and sequences we got in this film just feel like cheap knockoffs. The story is paced nicely and relatively makes sense, we had interesting characters, good and bad, but all in all this film feels like a cheap money grab, and you can definitely go without seeing this.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The portrayal of Snow's rise to power was intriguing, unraveling the influences that shaped him into an evil dictator. However, the absence of exploration into Lucy Grey's character, possibly related to Katniss Everdeen, felt like a missed opportunity. Initially thinking Snow was her father added to the confusion. The focus solely on Snow's story left Lucy Grey's role largely unexplored, and her country-like singing style seemed out of place, disrupting the movie's flow. The film's pacing felt extended, making it dull and failing to engage with some characters that should have received more attention. This ambiguity made it challenging to define whether the movie leaned towards drama or adventure.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Just finished watching the new Hunger Games movie, and I have mixed feelings about it. It felt a bit disappointing, to be honest. The movie leans heavily on shallow acting and a fairly simplistic musical style that might find an audience among certain viewers, but for me, it didn't quite click. Spending three hours on it left me wanting more. I was expecting a deeper level of storytelling and quality, especially considering the high bar set by previous installments in the series. While it might resonate with those seeking more straightforward entertainment, it lacked the intricate storytelling and character depth that made the earlier movies so compelling. It's not that it's terrible, but it didn't live up to the series' legacy for me.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Unlike mockingjay I actually feel like this film could have been split in two. We grow to love Lucy gray Baird and we even like corialanus snow at the start as it's human nature to gravitate towards the main character of a film. The hunger games themselves are great but then the second half of the film is a total contrast to the first and it's a shame that we see both the blossoming of Lucy gray baird and corialanus relationship in the same film.There's some superb songs in this and the soundtrack is great. Good to see why snow subconsciously hates 'katniss' almost straight away. I wonder if Lucy gray Baird survives. Interesting to see if there will be any more installments.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Having enjoyed the book so much, I was excited to watch the film. But the screen adaptation was lazily done and had to rush through what was a well-written story to squeeze itself into a film.The character of Corialanus was completely lost on screen and became an empty, 2D version of what he should have been. He became en empty villain character- no complexity, no human element whatsoever.The Hunger Games has an important place in literature and film because it speaks a message to young people about fairness, power and kindness to others but this message was on completely lost in a stupidly rapid, thin narrative.A bit embarrassing tbh.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I was pleased by this movie. This movie was probably the darkest Hunger Games yet, likely due to its more archaic technology used relative to the previous films. The acting was goods. Say what you want about Zelger, but her acting in this film was definitely a highlight. This film also gives us a better look at the function and reasoning behind this autocratic government, which is build under the principle that "humans are inherently violent, and we need to be reminded of who we are." This movie is not flawless though. There are 2 major flaws with this movie: 1) An overly confusing plot, and 2) Subpar story arcs. The plot was a lot like Oppenheimer, where it is a 3 act structure, yet the most action happens in the second act, and the third act is the aftermath. With Oppenheimer though, it at least remained grounded through the entire movie with its philosophical and ethical questions. In this Hunger Games movie, the third act seems to diverge into something really weird with not much direction, and it really only makes sense when it is over. Now to Snow's story arc; it is completely lopsided. This movie is supposed to be a villain origin story, yet we see him as a protagonist all the way until the very end, with not much really much leading up to it, other than maybe a few warning signs. Lucy Grey's story arc is dull too. Why does she just all the sudden leave and try to kill Snow? Her purpose really was as a prop to Snow's already flawed story arc. There doesn't seem to be that character that you can really follow. Overall though, it is a good movie that is definitely worth a watch. The story is gripping, the villain is absolutely crazy (the scientist), and the dystopian themes are very convincing where you almost find yourself rationalizing the tyrannical government.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a prequel to the movie that launched the franchise, focusing on the origins of Panem's authoritarian leader Coriolanus Snow. The film is split into three chapters, delivering a trifecta of overwrought, overacted, and overlong. The adaptation of Suzanne Collins' novel explores the Hunger Games' origins and Snow's descent into the dark side. However, the new Snow, played by British actor Tom Blyth, is a bland construct, joining other privileged young Capitol residents as mentors to the youths chosen to compete and die as tributes. Snow is tasked with capturing Lucy Gray Baird, a talented actress from District 12. Snow is captivated by her talent and plans to help her survive the competition. However, he must navigate the eagle-eyed masterminds, Casca Highbottom (Peter Dinklage) and Volumnia Gaul (Viola Davis), who resembles Cruella de Vil in her appearance and line delivery. Lucy's success will be crucial in the film's success. "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a thrilling prequel based on Suzanne Collins' 2020 novel, focusing on Coriolanus Snow's rise to power. The film showcases Tom Blyth's transformation from a moneyed pretty boy to a clear-eyed manipulator, showcasing Snow's transformation from a destined greatness to a manipulator intent on crafting his fate. The film's gripping performances, including Donald Sutherland's portrayal of Snow, make it a captivating watch. Dr. Volumnia Gaul emphasizes the importance of creating memorable spectacles, with Viola Davis playing a chic, sadistic character with the right amount of camp, and costume designer Trish Summerville's striking creations benefiting her. Snow's dark side is revealed in "The Peacekeeper," a bold departure from previous chapters. The film moves from the austere Capitol to a pastoral forest setting, creating a romantic and dangerous atmosphere. The 157-minute film slows and quiets down, allowing for tension between two people who trust each other. Lucy Gray's folksy charm is used effectively, and the energy in the film is balanced by the lush, romantic, and dangerous atmosphere. "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a suspenseful prequel to Coriolanus's long-standing belief that snow always lands on top.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Why is everyone pronouncing it wrong in the movie?Too much singing. I don't know what's wrong with the girl's jaw. No chemistry between the leads.I liked the boy's performance in some scenes. Towards the end you kind of see him finally "bloom", only to hear the real Snow say the phrase "It is the things we love most, that destroy us", and have the illusion shattered. He didn't manage to get at the same level as the previous actor. But I don't think it was the actor's fault, he is very good in my opinion. I believe it was the directing that was misguided, following the book a bit too much.The Hunger Games books were very badly written. The movies I adore. Watched them a hundred times.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: While the movie is almost 3hrs long, it still feels too rushed. If it was broken up in half it would have been more enjoyable and the character development would have been better instead of what we got. I did enjoy it with my wife, but Hollywood needs to slow it down in order to gain another motion picture hit.Snow's character doesn't feel like he's getting darker as in the book but feels more like a crying child who isn't getting his own way with no major change in his mindset to life with the hunger games. There are some additions in the movie that has nothing to do with the book so anyone claiming its faithful needs to reread it again.Enjoyable for a one-time watch but that's all.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Films that epitomize the essence of movie-making often begin with a compelling story. "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is no exception, boasting an outstanding narrative alongside remarkable acting, producing, and cinematography that immerse you in its world. Although the film starts somewhat slowly, this cleverly serves as a plot device to foster empathy with the main characters, allowing us to see reflections of our own choices and dilemmas on the screen. Have you ever sacrificed something you love for a necessity? Have you made decisions that altered the course of your life? This movie explores these questions and more over its engaging two and a half hours. It reminds me of films like "Titanic," which don't just transport you away from your life but place you in another's shoes, prompting you to contemplate your own reactions in similar situations. For those who appreciate the preceding works, this film is a solid choice, paying a subtly ingenious tribute to its predecessors. It is replete with plot twists that cleverly subvert expectations. Special mention must go to the young actress McKenzie Lansing, who portrays a villainous character with a pitchfork. Though her role is brief, it is intensely visceral and memorable. In conclusion, this film truly encapsulates the author's vision for an engaging sequel.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I had heard many mixed reviews about this film, but since I am a fan of the series, and reading the book when it came out, I decided to give it a shot and I was not disappointed.The film is very faithful to the book, although the first part felt a bit off the side to me, I thought the film as a whole flowed well. The acting felt rather irritating at first, but I got used to it within the first part. Another con I found was that I also thought it would've worked better if it was a TV Series. There would've been more of an opportunity to actually go into depth about each character, because it didn't feel like we actually bonded with any of the characters, apart from Sejanus but even then in the end he turned about to be a bit of a jerk.Although I found it enjoyable, definitely too violent for a 12A, but the screenplay was entertaining, the cinematography was good. Worth a watch if you're a longtime fan.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes is the prequel to The Hunger Games, were they show us the first original beginnings of the games. Everything was less technological and looked more like a Gladiator arena, and here I could really feel that they were fighting to survive, the connection between the tributes was really strong, and they made that danger feeling much stronger in here, then in the original movies. It was also about the story of President Snow, how he started as a young man that had plans for a bright future, but ended with an evil path, with rage and madness. His story, and how his rage was evolving, was showed greatly, with complete understanding. The movie itself, did have dominating pros, but could have fixed some things. The pros, first of all, was amazing storytelling. They distributed the story in three parts, each chapter about a specific topic. I liked the prequel best from the franchise because it was richer story. In the originals, they focused mostly on one topic, but here, they included more of everything. Story, feelings and character development. President Snow as a character was amazingly performed by Tom Blyth, as a lost boy of perfection and squareness. Rachel Zegler as the songbird, Lucy Gray Bird, was the movies mystery. She was like an incomplete book, and made her more an interesting character. Rachel Zegler took her role, and personally, she is a very good singer, she is very pretty, but her acting is decent. Her acting could be better, her expressions could look more realistic. Her songs were good, though, they were mostly about the society and people of district twelve, and gave me a bigger understanding of their culture. The first Hunger Games was ok, but it always missed a puzzle. It didn't really explain the nature of the country, society and culture, something they did in this part, and made it finally a complete picture. Good scenography, editing and action sequences. The Hunger Games fights were very entertaining, very barbaric, and some of the kills were pretty well made, with good dramatical scenes and so. They could focus a little bit on the dialogues, more originality, even though it was good enough. The beginning with an impressive intro ended with a good, dramatical outro, and closed the movie complete. To conclude, this is the best Hunger Games so far, and I hope maybe some day the story will continue in a similar way as this one.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The movie portrays snow incredibly inaccurately. He has so much more depth than the movie shows. He is very young when the movie/book takes place and it shows when reading but not in the movie. It makes sense since the story has been condensed into one 2 hour and 40 minute long movie, I wish they would have made it two, two hour movies.Coriolanus Snow is a very calculated young kid but not like the movie portrays. In the movie he seemingly goes out of his way to cheat while in the book he does to accidentally or as an afterthought, he doesn't intend to but he does and then tries to justify it.Coriolanus is not a "cold blooded killer" despite how the movie portrays him. I've heard people call him that before. I think that when he runs away with Lucy, the reality of what he's doing starts to set in and to justify him wanting to leave and go back, his mind convinces him that she has figured everything out and is trying to kill him.Later when he goes back to the capitol and he starts looking for ways to improve the hunger games, I don't think he actually believes the hunger games to be the best solution. I think he sees the hunger games as the only solution. He knows that the children In the games are innocent and that they are real human beings, but he also believes that without the hunger games the capitol will be poor and he will have to go back to living like he and Lucy were planning to and that's his worst nightmare.Whenever he kills someone (in the book) he is finding a reason as to why it's justified and the reason is always for his personal gain, not because he simply wanted them dead. So in his mind he is most likely justifying the games as the only way for him to not go on to live "a poor lifestyle" again. It's okay to keep the hunger games going because it ensures that he doesn't have to "fraternise" with lower class people and it ensure that he won't fall in love with someone like Lucy Gray again.Coriolanus is all about power and control. Lucy Gray is his polar opposite. Coriolanus expresses how he felt that he lost control around Lucy Gray because he was in love with her. He then also explains how he never wants to feel that again and that if i is to have children it will be with someone he hates so that they can't control him.Even while Lucy Gray was in the arena he only wanted her to survive because he wanted her to stay in the capitol with him and not because he wanted her to live to see her family again, he wanted her because he loved her, but he didn't love her enough to become a part of her world.This movie is way to condensed to do the story justice, if only it had been two movies.TLDR: Snow is not a cold blooded killer who actively tries to cheat in the hunger games to win. He is a thoughtful kid obsessed with his own personal gain and wealth and he sees the hunger games as the only option to obtain that.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I blame it on Lucy Gray, a character so annoyingly righteous and vigorously rebellious that it was very difficult to connect to anything she touched. Fixing just this character would have made this film close to greatness, because almost everything else was good. The casting, the acting, the sets, the story.Tom Blyth was great, Viola David too. Most other characters were filler, but they were cast well and did their job. As opposed to the original trilogy of films, this felt more grounded, more mature. It wasn't perfect, but I enjoyed the film.There were three parts of the movie, the third felt the most rushed and frankly I would have probably liked the film more if it were not part of it. It would have also brought it to a normal length; I hate these modern three hours productions. If you can't tell your story in 2 hours, that's a problem. The story was intriguing, documenting in a tense and oppressive way the rise of a villain, I think one of the most entertaining types of tales out there, but the rushed third part muddled that a bit.I can't believe I am saying this, but this deserved a split into two films. As such, you are left with a bitter aftertaste, like someone took something that you felt had coming from you. Enough to turn one into a villain.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: A new entry in the franchise is now a prequel (taking place 10 years after the first Hunger Games) as we follow the rise of President Snow (essayed by Donald Sutherland in the first series) as a young man, Tom Blyth, who has seen the worse of the war alongside his sister, Euphoria's Hunter Schafer, but now live in the bustling metropolis of Panem awaiting news if he's won the coveted Plinth prize which his family desperately needs since their finances are on the wane. To add more stress, the new Hunger Games are upon them & the ratings are down so the game makers, Oscar winner Viola Davis & Peter Dinklage, will introduce to this new tourney having the contestants interact directly w/their mentors w/Blyth partnered w/Rachel Zegler (already tagged as someone to watch since when her name's announced she flings a snake in a rival's blouse & sings in defiance to her nomination). What follows is another battle royal (sorry since the Hunger Games were always pegged as American copies of that notorious Japanese classic) w/most of the gameplay located to one environment as we wait to see if Zegler will pull off a win. Francis Lawrence wisely returns back to the fold after directing 3 previous entries already & his knowledge of the material works well enough to mount something familiar which still manages to rankle some genuine tension & disgust at the extreme politics seen on screen (maybe something The Phantom Menace wanted to do?) w/the performances fine & flinty which makes me wonder if there's enough fire in Suzanne Collins' belly to put out more installments to be filmed.
