Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I was thoroughly enjoying this... until it absolutely nosedives during the latter half.'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' starts off so strongly, continuing at a pleasant pace as it encompasses the Hunger Games itself. However, from the end of the event it truly does drop off a cliff out of nowhere. The film gives you a major high of action with the games, then drops the tempo down to such a slow first act-esque pace that it feels extremely tacked on.I did enjoy the cast throughout, mostly. Tom Blyth is excellent, first time I've seen him properly in a film and I was very impressed; though even his performance suffers with the aforementioned, which for him is from the point that he becomes The Real Slim Shady, seemingly (his originally look is so much better). Still, I'm eager to see that guy act further.Rachel Zegler is largely good, though does chew the scenery quite a bit in parts; predominantly when singing. Viola Davis is great, while Peter Dinklage is underused but still a positive. Jason Schwartzman and Josh Andrés Rivera, meanwhile, are solid enough supports.Just a shame about the final act. It's not necessarily that bad in itself, but to lower the pace that sharply after such prolonged thrill is a recipe for disaster. So much so that it makes the whole part drag hard, or perhaps 'twas just so for me?

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I never read the books the original films, or this one, were adapted from. Consequently, I was somewhat lost at times and it almost felt as though this prequel needed its *own* prequel since characters acted like/referred to things as if we should know WHY they acted that way/what they were talking about. This is where book-readers will have an advantage over non-book-readers, as they'll *know* why certain characters are acting the way they do with others, etc. Of course, the downside to being a book-reader is that you'll no doubt be overly critical about every little detail, things you imagined differently, changes made, and things left out or added in. The benefit I had was judging this movie solely based on its own merits, coming into it fresh and with little idea of what would be happening (other than seeing the origin of how Snow turned evil).The movie's broken up into three parts titled 'The Mentor', 'The Prize' and 'The Peacekeeper'. Tom Blyth as a pre-Donald Sutherland version of Coriolanus Snow proves himself a capable leading man, as his character goes through quite the journey in the film and he rises to every occasion, playing all the different facets of Snow's personality in his early life. He starts out as someone whose main motivation is a monetary prize, but then this 'rebel' (who's referred to as such on more than one occasion) becomes invested for more personal reasons in the survival of the tribute he's selected to play mentor to: Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler). I feel some have been unfairly critical of Zegler's performance, letting the things she's said in interviews (that've rattled some feathers...but have absolutely *nothing* to do with how she plays her character here) colour their judgement. I personally thought she held her own against Blyth's Snow admirably. As Lucy Gray describes herself, she's 'not made of sugar', and this becomes abundantly clear during her introduction when she drops a snake down the back of a girl's dress. Then later, during Lucy Gray's first meeting with Coriolanus, she eats a petal off the white rose he presents her with (which definitely leaves an impression).People have complained about 'too much singing' in the movie (but it's RIGHT THERE in the title: 'The BALLAD of SONGbirds & Snakes'), but don't be scared of the singing...the movie's not a 'musical' like some have made it out to be. While Zegler certainly puts the 'song' in 'songbird' by providing the majority of the film's soundtrack, it's part of her character (and actually an important plot point). Plus, she can really hold a tune...so why the complaining? It'd be one thing if she sang BADLY, but she gives the songs her all, putting emotion/feeling into every one (and it's not over-polished, which is appreciated). The film rests mainly on these two actors' shoulders, and I personally found their scenes together to be the most compelling parts of the movie. Lucy Gray starts out not trusting Coriolanus, but he shows her on more than one occasion that he isn't without heart and gradually she grows to trust him, as they work together to ensure her survival in the Hunger Games.Another stand-out in the cast is Jason Schwartzman as Lucretius "Lucky" Flickerman, weatherman and aspiring magician (who bears an uncanny resemblance to Stanley Tucci's Caesar Flickerman from the original films), as his reporting the weather while kids are dying in the arena provides some morbid humour at one point (really, he's the only source of 'humour' in the film). Head Gamemaker, Dr. Volumnia Gaul is a frightful sight (her makeup's seriously unnerving) and you can't help but wonder if the reason everyone's so hungry is because Viola Davis keeps devouring all the scenery. Her rainbow of snake muttations are a colourful way to take out the stragglers when there is only a handful left. Speaking of, I remember the acting for the tributes who weren't Katniss (whose name I was surprised to learn the origin of in this film) or Peeta in the original films was pretty sketchy...and it hasn't really improved this time around. Other than one or two who make the most of their limited screentime (that we either feel sorry for, as they're practically Dead Meat Walking, or are shown to be more three-dimensional than they first appeared), the majority feel barely above CW teen drama levels in the acting department.Much better are other supporting characters such as Dean Casca Highbottom (Peter Dinklage, continuing to play characters who drink and know things...that is until the end when he *doesn't* know something, which proves fatal), Sejanus Plinth (Josh Andrés Rivera, playing a friend of Coriolanus and a fellow mentor who won't stand for the Games' barbarity...which also proves fatal) and Tigris (Hunter Schafer, playing cousin to Coriolanus...or 'Coryo' as she calls him, who I found particularly interesting to watch and really enjoyed her scenes with Blyth's Snow). Something this movie has definitely stepped up from the previous films is the brutality of the Games, as there's no shortage of death (so don't get too attached to anyone). I also found the themes explored in the movie felt more 'mature' and there was a complexity that you might miss the intricacies of if you're not paying attention.Although it may seem like the film loses some steam in its third part, it's necessary to show that things aren't all fine and dandy after the Games are over with. The relationship between Coriolanus and Lucy Gray is not one that's wrapped up in a nice neat little bow. There's an open-endedness that may frustrate some people, but the important thing is that by the film's end...The President Snow of the future has been born/created. On the whole, I found the movie held my attention throughout (not a small feat considering its runtime) and I liked it better than the first, third and fourth previous films. Only the second film, Catching Fire, would I rank higher than this one.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Even for those unfamiliar with THE HUNGER GAMES, this film is often engaging. Knowledge of the series adds depth to the film. The titular games provide plot momentum ans suspense. Once the games end, the film's forward trajectory meanders. The performances are outstanding.The story of Coriolanus Snow, years before he would become the tyrannical President of Panem. He is handsome and charming, and though the Snow family has fallen on hard times, Coriolanus sees a chance for a change in his fortunes when he is chosen to be a mentor for the 10th Hunger Games only to have his elation dashed when he is assigned to mentor a girl tribute named Lucy Gray Baird from the impoverished District 12.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: As someone who eagerly awaited each 'Hunger Games' movie release, I was excited after 8 years to finally get more.I have not yet read the books so it was interesting seeing the film unravel and seeing just how Snow came to be.The film, I would say, is the weakest of the films by a good stretch. The pacing was rather odd. At times it would feel like the film was rushing through scenes and then at other times, spending way too much time on scenes that don't really further the narrative or show off the characters in any meaningful way.The performances were good but the side characters performances stood out so much more than our primary protagonist.The production and costume design was great, as was the soundtrack.

Reviewer_Content: Giving this an 7/10 ratingWas film really needed, not really, but the story of how Coriolanus Snow, came to be how he is, and the Huger Games, themselves, is a good story.Rachel Zegler and Tom Blyth as Snow, they are the ones who carry the film and that respect, they do not disappoint, Viola Davis si quite unique and he make up helps, she is so different. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: In 2008, Suzanne Collins took the young adult world by storm with the publication of The Hunger Games, soon turned into a global phenomenon movie franchise with the first entry coming out as early as 2012. With hindsight, it's the political vision infused in The Hunger Games that is most striking. Panem reflects a vision of the United States where a small group of economic, intellectual and artistic elites live extravagantly in rich cities, devoid of true human values, while the rest of the country lives in poverty, working hard and sustaining traditional values and human authenticity. Whether you share this vision or not, it is hard to disagree that it reflected well-ahead of its time a political view that millions of Americans (and others in the world) would embrace a few years later.Now, eight years after the last installment in the series, a prequel is released that tells the origin story of the franchise villain, Coriolanus Snow. Let it be said that the film succeeds in building an engaging story about the development of this character, one that is full of action, excitement and well-crafted character development. However, more than Snow's origin story, it's the origin story of Panem and the Capitol that catches our attention, given the strength of the political message in the first four films. In The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, we are presented with a Capitol that looks very different from the one seen in the previous films. Instead of the extravagant town reflective of liberal cities in the US, we see a grey city, built in massive concrete structures, that is highly reminiscent of the image we have of Soviet or Eastern European communist cities in the 70's and 80's. The structures, the clothes, the sculptures towering over giant squares, the cars, the propaganda posters are all reflective of communist imagery. That is ultimately the subversive political message infused into this prequel: the behavior and decadence of the Capitol (and by extension of liberal American cities) has its roots in communism. For anyone who understood the political message in the first four films and its connection with some political views in America, this conclusion is not unexpected, but it is certainly a bit disturbing to see it so prominently displayed in such a mass-market oriented movie targeting the young.In the spirit of open-mindedness and democratic values, one can still choose to appreciate and enjoy the film without agreeing with its political message (something many are unable to do these days). There is for example no doubt that the Soviet imagery creates an amazing visual experience, in particular with the representation of a hunger games arena that is visually impactful and very different from the one in previous installments.Ultimately, The Hunger Games is an exciting franchise and this new installment is no exception. And whether you agree with its political vision or not, history has told us that it has had a way of being ahead of its time, and therefore that it is worth listening to.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I've always had a soft spot for the Hunger Games franchise since it was the first time I made an effort to read the books before the films came out. I think the first two films are genuinely fantastic which still holds up really well despite the overindulgent 3rd and 4th films disappointing me. I've been excited for this film since it was announced cause I just love the world that's been created for this series and I really enjoyed the book of Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes. While the film itself isn't free from all the book's shortcoming, I still really enjoyed seeing another movie set in this world.The great world building from the original trilogy continues to be a massive positive here. I loved the retro-futuristic aesthetic and this film manages the capture the inherent terror that comes from this premise. This is something the f original excelled at and none of the sequels quite recaptured. The tension leading up to the start of the games is so well captured, it's terrifying to put yourself in the situation of these characters and it's exceedingly more gritty and graphic than any of the other movies. There were more genuinely disturbing moments than I expected there to be, even having read the book, and it's by far the darkest entry in the franchise.I really liked the tone of this movie. It's a villain origin first and foremost and the script takes its time to develop this twisted romance and how it leads to the downfall of Snow as a person. We're definitely not watching Jennifer Lawrence's character and Tom Blyth does such a good job at giving small hints to the ferocious nature of this character. He's great and so is Rachel Zegler in what I think may be my favourite performance from her. She's a great singer, (we knew that from West Side Story) which this character does a lot of, she's great in all the action scenes and her chemistry with Blyth phenomenally realises the growing wedge between this pair until it comes to ahead very well I think.Like the novel, I do think it's a bit long in the tooth. At over 2 and a half hours there's a lot of material being explored and it can make the first two acts feel quite scatter shot. The first act in particular feels a bit too quick cut, the second act isn't quite a tight as it could've been and the third act takes quite a sudden turn which I was prepared for but did feel a bit jarring. I did think reading the book that an adaption could lend itself better to a miniseries and having seen the film now I don't necessarily think I was wrong in that belief.I also think the characters as a whole are a bit of a mixed bag. I loved the central pair, Peter Dinklage's character and Viola Davis' deliciously over the top villain but most of the others were fairly one note. Josh Andrés Rivera's character was a high point from the book but I don't think he's that well realised here. I found him quite naive and not in an endearing way to the point where I didn't really care much when he was on screen. Most the students characters are just there to be classist caricatures without much depth and the tributes get some nice moments but it's obvious they're not the focus.It's definitely indulgent and scattershot but as a fan of the book and this series as a whole, I really enjoyed The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes as an adaptation. It's considerably darker than most YA adaptions, not to mention more graphic, and I could be more critical of certain aspects but as a fan I just couldn't help but enjoy the experience of this movie. I would comfortably put this as my 3rd favourite Hunger Games movie and if we don't get anymore this is without the best adaption of a YA movie series we've had since the Harry Potter franchise.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This just wasn't it for me, maybe because I haven't really delved into the rest of the films - or I am not as emotionally attached to this series. I think it was a bit of swing and a miss.I thought it looked great, don't get me wrong this film looks and sounds great too - although I think this could be a borderline musical really but that's beside the point. Set design, costume, sound all of this was good and intriguing to the eye and fits perfectly into the series without any raised eyebrows.The story was somewhat ok and I think what knocked it for me was that it was very drawn out (I haven't read the book so it may be very faithful) but I thought that this could of been sped up somewhat. I found this film came into its own too late, and is mainly the reason why I found it long and perhaps a bit tedious.Action sequences where good, characters were certainly hit and miss, Violet Davis' is someone I would happily not see again.I feel this was a good attempt, but just missed the mark for me personally.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I have never read the books before and it has been many years since I watched the movies. But I really enjoyed this film. Racheal Zeglar is awesome. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I tried to watch this film. I was a fan of both the original series books and films. I haven't read the book this latest film was based on, and after watching the film (as much as I could stand), I likely won't bother.What the previous books and films did well (for the most part) was convince you a world where society was so broken that people would watch children slaughter each other on tv was possible. They built a universe with a history, characters, and circumstances that made sense, despite their extreme nature.But this film did none of that. We're introduced to characters, the protagonists, who immediately seem absurd. It was like they were trying to channel Harry Potter in a world that was never about magic, but instead about human evolution under extreme forces.One of the protagonists starts randomly singing while in Renaissance Faire cosplay within the first 20 minutes. People in the audience sing back-up. Why?! It was sentimental, saccharin and just silly. We don't even know these characters yet, but should buy that they're singing sending the protagonist off to die?I tried to continue watching, but none of the actors even seem to be in the same room as each other. Their interactions are unbelievable; Rachel clearly does not understand the tone of these stories and seems like she's been involuntarily transported from a Broadway stage. I didn't make it past the tv introductions of tribute and mentor scene, not even 30 minutes in. I can't stand terrible films, and this one just wasn't worth my time.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: We left the theater after fighting to stay awake and make sense of this movie. Really hard to follow and get excited about anything. Can I get a refund????I don't know who the REAL target audience was, but if you watched the original series of movies that were good, this one just made no sense. The depiction of a future higher class society is was annoying and ridiculous.The main actors did well and that is the only reason we stay as long as we did, but the story line and everything else was just off the charts bad. I wish Jennifer Lawrence would have been cast somehow, she really made the other movies great.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: To start off with, if you didn't read the book, you likely won't like the movie, or so I've seen. That being said, I highly recommend picking up the book (yes it is in fact the longest one yet).TBSS was a long overdue return to Panem and was a story that was well received by the screen. Cinematically, the movie had some amazing shots and close ups that superseded its predecessors. This is in no doubt thanks to the almost ten years that have elapsed since the last installment in the franchise.As for chemistry, the tension between Blyth and Ziegler was alive and well and really took over during the evening visit to the zoo. Ziegler delivered nothing less than a stellar performance through every song, even though I initially thought there were one too many original songs in the book (sorry Collins). The soundtrack makes for a great transportation back to the movie after having seen it, though the downfall is that it does not stand alone like the previous soundtracks in the franchise did. Oh, how I wish Lorde had returned, or even Coldplay.In regard to its faithfulness to the book, the movie did a decent job of retaining the truth from its source material. The only major complaint I had was the extreme passage of time during the third part. At the same time, I argue the lengths at which Collins spent in that third part could have been cut shorter, so I understand the choice to skip over some sections. There was also a lack of development regarding Corio's and Sejanus' friendship. It felt very low stakes and was probably underdeveloped due to the lack of time spent in Part 3. I also have to argue that the last scene (you know the one I'm talking about) was a forced perspective of Snow's, so the audience can only help but think he's in the right, that is unless you've read the book and can understand his irrational paranoia. I also believe there was some essential dialogue cut that Casca Highbottom says at the end that explains Snow's motivations. Alas they got most of the book right, enough for me not to notice anything else.Overall, The Balls of Songbirds & Snakes delivered on almost every promise that the previous Hunger Games movie couldn't. We saw plenty of the Capitol. The director/writer did a wonderful job at humanizing the tributes, something the other movies failed at, which is very meta as they talk about trying to do so in the very book itself. The movie did well being split into three separate parts, once again nodding to the source material. Even without the internal dialogue offered by the book, Blyth's downward spiral into the president we came to know back in 2012 was honest and believable. I enjoyed the nods to previous books and movies and certainly enjoyed the cameo at the end. I am not one to see movies twice in the theaters, but this one might deserve a second go.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is based on the novel of the same name, by Suzanne Collins. It is set 64 years before the events of The Hunger Games(2012). Coriolanus Snow(Tom Blyth) mentors District 12 tribute, Lucy Gray Baird(Rachel Zegler). Soon, he develops feelings for her.The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a good film. However, The Hunger Games(2012), The Hunger Games: Catching Fire(2013), The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1(2014) & The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2(2015) surpass this prequel by a huge margin. Director Francis Lawrence can't recapture lightning in a bottle, directing his fourth movie in the Hunger Games franchise. The first half of the film is mind-blowing. However, it goes off the rails in the second half. The movie gets super dragging & goes on & on, with no end in sight. Another negative is, there are too many songs for a Hunger Games film. The action set pieces are fantastic & look even better in IMAX. The visual effects are flawless. Tom Blyth is impressive as Coriolanus Snow. Rachel Zegler is brilliant as Lucy Gray Baird. Hunter Schafer is perfect as Tigris Snow. Viola Davis is spectacular as Dr. Volumnia Gaul. Peter Dinklage is outstanding as Dean Casca Highbottom. Josh Andres Rivera is superb as Sejanus Plinth. The supporting cast is unforgettable. The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is worth a watch if you're a fan of the Hunger Games movies & novels. However, watch it with low expectations & you just might enjoy yourself.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I am not a huge fan of the Hunger Games franchise but have seen some of the other films. This effort felt overlong, I really can't see why they couldn't have told exactly the same story in 45 minutes less. There's too much filler and needless scenes that,if anything, should have been used to develop the characters more.The singing became a distraction and was overused, the violence was almost fetishised, with too much time and effort put into it at the expense of the relationships between the key characters. Plot twists and turns were never particularly explored or explained, and felt pretty arbitrary. I am guessing the book provides far greater depth than was achieved in this film.The lead actors never really achieved great chemistry and their relationship was, again pretty shallow to begin with,and wasn't given adequate time to grow and evolve.I can't say I hated the movie but I'd definitely not rush to watch it again, I doubt I'll remember much about it in a couple of weeks time.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I was pleasantly surprised with The Hunger Games: A Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, in that it was a perfectly paced film, which balanced particularly dark action and thought-provoking themes very well. In addition, it set up the first The Hunger Games perfectly, something I felt the book was a little unclear on. I was worried that Lucy Gray's constant singing, as is in the book, would take over the film, but it was perfectly placed and necessary. All in all, a really entertaining watch for Hunger Games fans with some fantastic foreshadowing scenes and quotes that were far from cheesy. This felt like Suzanne Collins wrote the script, unlike in the Mockingjay Part 1 & 2 - a film definitely worth your time.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: It's a savage, 1984 dystopian satire, on class inequality. It's dark, not a young adult action flick like the original Hunger Games trilogy or the first Mazerunner movie. Would have done better at box-office released in October for Halloween?Best acting is by an unrecognizable Viola Davis (The Woman King). She's a mad scientist supper-villain--yet, not over-done. If Donald Sutherland was 10/10 crazy, she takes "unhinged" to 11. Impressive. She commits to showing the ugliest and unpleasant aspect of dissociated economic elites.Using title cards, the movie is divided into three acts. The end of the second act is the highpoint of the film. DON'T MISS IT! Brilliant and amazing filmmaking! Afterwards, I was half ready for the credits to roll. Yet it goes on for another 45 minutes to show us how young Snow became old Snow in the trilogy.The King's Man (2021) had a similar problem. The film peaked at the end of the first act. For Hollywood blockbusters, both The King's Man and this film are original and narratively unorthodox. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I never thought I needed another Hunger Games movie, especially a prequel without Jennifer Lawrence. However this movie was incredible and I feel like it added a lot to the franchise. Suzanne Collins added so much interesting depth and background for President Snow here and the script did a great job adapting her story. Collins doesn't get enough credit for how insightful and impactful her work really is. This movie is a slow burn where we see Snow fall into darkness and I love how subtle the character work is. He doesn't feel like he just snaps, it feels like a progression of his character as he interprets a new meaning of what the Hunger Games mean. Tom Blyth was phenomenal as a young Coriolanus Snow. He had so much range and we were able to understand how this villain we hate in the original movies was formed. His relationship with Lucy Gray was perfectly done. Say what you want about Rachel Zegler but she can ACT. She captured Lucy Gray so well and I love the incorporation of the musical performances. I thought it was really cool how we learn that Lucy values trust over love and the moment she feels she can't trust Snow, she turns on him. The impact this has on Snow is his final breaking point and I love how this scene is handled. The way she leaves him by singing the Hanging Tree is brilliant and adds so many layers to Snow's character in the original films. The entire supporting cast is also good, with Viola Davis being the standout. The action scenes are intense for the most part although I don't feel like the arena scenes were as good as the original movies. The film has excellent atmosphere building and the set design and costumes are top tier just like they always are in the Hunger Games franchise. Francis Lawrence once again did a great job directing. There were lots of great scenes and shots throughout. A highlight for me was the scene where Lucy is singing into the camera in the arena as the snakes sliver around her body. I thought the movie had some pacing issues but nothing that was really that big of a deal. Overall this was a prequel that is worthy of the originals while also telling its own great story. 8/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I missed the start of this because for some reason the cinema didn't play any trailers, so I felt like I was playing catch up with the characters and their dynamics for a little while (I came in on the scene in which the mentors are told whom they're going to be mentoring, so I can't have missed that much). When the film was over, I worked out I must have only missed seven minutes, so I guess that most of the audience was playing catch up along with me (that can't be Lucy Gray's literal introduction, can it?). Basically what I'm saying is that a lot of the context I assumed I missed because I was late is actually just missing from the piece full stop, and it's something that plagues the entirety of the picture. Where 'The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1 (2014)' and 'The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 (2015)' ought to have been split into a single movie with a runtime not dissimilar from that of this film, 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad Of Songbirds & Snakes (2023)' (that's one too many "The"s, by the way) really ought to have been split into two separate movies with runtimes similar to those films. So much of this is far too rushed for its own good, and - although the flick hits the ground running and leaves little room for boredom, at least initially - this is ultimately the main flaw of the feature. There are plenty of genuinely interesting ideas at play here, with the picture following a character who comes to realise that his own self-interest might just take precedent over helping other people (or generally doing the right thing) when circumstances force him to choose between the two. Its grey morality is fairly refreshing, and having someone who isn't a hero be the protagonist of a wide-appeal blockbuster - particularly one based on young adult fiction - is quite ballsy. The problem is that none of its ideas get the time they need to feel fully formed. There's very little granularity to the character arcs and the most important relationships never feel genuine because they aren't really given all that much attention. There are solid scenes that focus on character work, but they're almost like milestones that the flick unceremoniously sprints past and are much harder to appreciate because of it. The film is at its best during the eponymous Hunger Games, as its distinct mentor-tribute relationship and Capitol-based perspective set it apart from the other films in its series. There's a lot of tension and suspense during this second act, and it generally keeps you on the edge of your seat. The pacy first part also features some compelling, if all too brief, set-up for this segment, establishing a more rudimentary rule set for the barbaric situation and having the lead make headway in transforming it into the entertainment-as-punishment we recognise from the other films in the franchise. It's all rather entertaining, even if it does leave you feeling a bit breathless. After the games, though, the feature slams on the brakes and slows to a crawl. The pacing almost entirely resets, and what follows is both too long to be an epilogue and too short to be its own thing. Again, it introduces some thoroughly intriguing ideas and it does have some really engaging moments, but it just doesn't have time to do anything with its ideas and ultimately ends with a bit of a whimper. That's not to say the ending is especially bad, but it does leave you thinking "that's it?" (despite the fact that it's technically quite well-rounded). The tragedy of the plot doesn't really come through as well as it ought to, and the ending doesn't have the intimacy in character behind it to justify its comparatively tiny scope. The formal successes of every technical department go under the radar, too, because of the underwhelming way in which the narrative is faithfully yet insufficiently adapted from the source material (which I haven't read). The writing really is the only thing holding this back, as it's a well-made effort with solid performances and some really entertaining sequences. It is enjoyable and some of it is surprisingly intellectually stimulating, but it could have been so much better with just a few small yet significant tweaks.P. S. It's kind of weird how it's essentially a musical, but I don't mind that.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a riveting return to Panem that boasts an exceptional cast and an exciting storyline. While the story is well-crafted, it can feel inconsistent at times. However, the film's captivating visuals are the true highlight, with expertly chosen lighting, lenses, and angles adding depth and dimension to each shot.Overall, The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes is a worthy addition to the franchise that adds depth to a significant character. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes" is a film any novice Hunger Games fan can enjoy.A look into Panem around the tenth Hunger Games, over 60 years before Catniss' first games, shows a whole different world. The war still lays fresh in the minds of Capital citizen as the rebuild begins, yet the spirit of rebellion still lives in the Districts. Nobody has a full grasp on how to handle the controversial Hunger Games, or even if it will continue, yet the show goes on. IThen comes a young Coriolanus Snow, who revolutionizes the way the Games are approached while mentoring a young girl from District 12, Lucy Gray Baird. Here, the sadistic and narcissist mindset of the President Snow we love to hate is born. His keen insight and manipulative attitude develops into a killing spree born of a deep hunger for power.Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage are brilliant as usual. Not impressed with Rachel Zegler as lead actress (she is no Jennifer Lawrence after all), but Tom Blyth as Snow heads the cast well and encapsulates the persona of President Snow subtly as the film continues.Like I said, any novice Hunger Games fan can enjoy the fascinating and intriguing parallels between this film and the iconic trilogy. While it can never be compared to its successor, "The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes" brings justice to the Suzzane Collins' world.Yes, it's drawn out a bit in the middle... get over it.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: How do you create a tyrant? Well let's see, you begin by dismantling him and bring him up in a nation and a world full of venomous snakes (so to speak), and then you take that man, and you begin to unravel him. Nothing says blood and more blood than the fact that you cannot get it out, it leaves a nasty scar, and it stains too, not just on clothes, but your cold, cold heart.There is no wander Suzanne Collins wanted to revisit Panem, she wanted to tell the story of how one kid became a ruthless dictator and the why and how behind it. Now I refuse to sit here and tell the story, no I will let you be the judge and character of that. This prequel will not only be the greatest in this series, but I will say Francis Lawrence has done it yet again.Nothing screams blockbuster, then this one. This move has defied all odds or as the tagline for the series says, "may the odds be ever in your favor." The odds are that you will not survive the arena. The entire cast was just phenomenal and the storyline leading up to the first movie left a lot of holes filled in. This cast including the talented and most gorgeous one of all.... Ms. Viola Davis, she can be sinister and yes, I have seen it, but not this sinister. To the newcomer Tom Blyth, congratulations dude, you just made Donald Sutherland very proud.To the beautiful Rachel Zegler, I said this for West Side Story, and I will say it again, seductively incredible - I cannot begin to tell you how incredible you were. To the rest of the cast Peter Dinklage, Hunter Schaefer - awesome.Thank you, Suzanne, for bringing us back to Panem, we have lost it over the last 9 years since Mockingjay, Part 2 - thank you, thank you.This movie was in a word sinister and wonderful rise to the threat of Panem through the eyes of Coriolanus Snow.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: That's the whole point of this prequel, Snow's transition to embodiment of Lawful Evil, isn't it? Francis Lawrence has so many things to tell and maintains the pace of the story, but at the last minute starting from 'Part 3: The Peacekeeper', he crams all those and develops so hastily that I am short of breath just by watching. It loses all coherence and logic along the way.Ironically, this film makes me realize that Jennifer Lawrence, Josh Hutcherson, and Donald Sutherland trio is the best you can ask for. Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: As a fan of all four books, I felt that the original trilogy missed the mark at many moments and overall could not deliver all of the things that truly made the books great.This movie however, succeeded.Although much of the movie is condensed due to time constraints, I felt that this adaptation still preserved every important beat of the story and the tone of almost every scene. At the TBOSAS core, it is a story about Coriolanus' view of humanity and him ultimately coming to the conclusion, as is the point of the games, that humans are inherently evil and the world is cruel. In a cruel world with malevolent beings filling it, why not be the man in charge? Why not be cruel right back to the world and kill and starve others? This story shows Coriolanus get to this state of mind, however misguided his cognitive journey may be. It is the story of a man losing any semblance of morals he had and losing his own humanity in order to become the powerful villain of the main trilogy. 100% worth the watch (even if you did not read the book).

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: 64 years prior to the original we see what Panem was like in the early days of its fascist rule a mere 10 years after the civil war ended.Lucy Gray is a friendly, sweet travelling performer... with a distinct edge beneath. Rachel Zegler's singing and acting are excellent, though do take a few minutes to get used to, and certainly I get why some say that there are too many musical interludes here. I acknowledge that some of the things she's said show that she's not the best feminist yet - let's please keep in mind, she's 22 years old. I would definitely say she's well on her way. Give her some time to have more life experience and reflect on these things more, and I'm sure she'll get there.It has been 8 years since we last got an entry in this film series. Some would say that the moment has passed. And that this does not have enough new material to justify making it. That it smacks of corporate greed. In my opinion, this was the exact perfect time to make another one. Allow me to explain why.This is the first of these to be made after the PG-13 rating was pushed so far that it could properly allow for coming extremely close to showing the bloody violence that the subject matter requires. While this is not as intense as certain parts of the Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 3, it is very obvious that it came out after that one, rather than shortly after the first one. The action and tension are the most visceral yet, and each death hits you like a sledgehammer. They're also the most clear and well-staged, easy to follow with one very effective long take.Some of the central issues that this franchise provides social commentary on have become worse and/or visible to a general audience. Regular people are forced to work ridiculously hard for less than a living wage, while the rich live a sheltered existence - it's very telling that several major characters in this feel no fear of actual danger, but instead consider their potential embarrassment to be a fate far worse than the certain death of 23 teenagers that had no way to avoid becoming Tributes.The youngest generations find themselves in a world where they have to be constantly camera ready, and the gig economy provides what little they have to live on. They either grow up too quickly or seemingly not at all, while their elders, those with significant power, who have created the current terrible conditions, judge them harshly, sitting in their ivory towers, insisting that it couldn't be any other way. 18-year-old Coriolanus Snow is influenced by several people in his life who try to encourage him to go in specific directions, and the potential for the future that he and his peers at least hypothetically hold is underlined; to either create a better society, or destroy all hope of it for generations to come - to let nationalists completely eliminate civil rights of anyone they deem lesser, or to wrestle back control.Those reporting on deadly conflicts may not actually care, or feel they have any skin in the game, and might treat it with little sensitivity, provide no context and simply try to get great ratings. There was never a long period of this movie that did not make me reflect on incredibly sad recent news stories. I understand that this is a negative for many, and I 100% respect those who disagree with the following; I don't go to movies to turn off my brain and be completely distracted from tough reality. I go for something that will help me process it better. And this absolutely delivered that.I recommend this to anyone who believes they can handle it - you'll know a few minutes in. 8/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is a good film that, as a prequel, managed to interest me in its story without having first seen the other films or read the "The Hunger Games" novels. The production is of a spectacular level, the script divided into three acts is effective, the first is dramatic and manages to generate sympathy with the main characters, the second act has good action scenes and manages to have good tension that makes you worry about the characters, but the third and last act is weak, slow but has well-directed dramatic moments. The performances are good, highlighting Rachel Zegler who also shows off her voice in several songs, and Viola Davis brings to life a unique character. The cinematography is not excellent but it does its job. The music composed for the film is its greatest success, highlighting the dramatic, action and suspense scenes. A film that manages to be good, but could have gone further with a better structured script in its final act.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: In the early days of the Hunger Games, poorly-off Panem Capital aristo Coriolanus Snow becomes mentor to District 12 tribute Lucy Grey Baird. In the course of trying new ideas, such as getting the audience to like Lucy (she's a good singer), he falls for her and determines to make sure she survives.I quite enjoyed the books and the previous films so I was up for a prequel (I haven't read the prequel novel). And it's not bad. The war is much more recent, which shows everywhere - even the capital is somewhat down-at-heel. Everything is considerably lower tech, and the film portrays a believable earlier era to what we have previously seen.The cast are fine, with Peter Dinklage's final scene showing what a great actor he is, and Viola Davies delivering a character even more cold-blooded and scary than Amanda Waller.And the story is involving and often goes in unexpected directions. At 150+ minutes, my attention never wandered.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This movie could have stood to be thirty minutes to an hour shorter. Two and half hours is plenty of time to develop a little backstory on more characters than just Snow. In the original films, I feel like they were able to help people get to know and understand a lot of the main characters. In this prequel, the only people we really come to understand are Snow, Tigress, and Plinth. I wish they would have showed more of the past of Lucy, the original game maker, and even some of the other hunger games tributes. Even the game maker with all her creatures-I wish they would have given even a line as to why she's into that stuff and how she got into it.As for the singing, I found it all very annoying and cringey. Most of the songs actually have a positive tone, which is strange for such a dark story. Lucy also chooses to sing at times that are really weird and don't make sense. She's also exaggerated-her southern accent, her personality, her facial expressions, everything. It's like I'm watching a musical rather than a serious movie. It's also like if you go to Disney and see performers put on a show and do a musical number for guests-it's that over the top. Also, I wish Lucy just used a flat, America/midwest kind of accent-that would have made it 100% better.Lastly, without giving spoilers, Snow makes some decisions that impact his trajectory and I wish they would have had some more lead up to those decisions. Like there isn't enough character development to get him there on some of those early decisions. I think things all end up making sense in the end, but it was a tough journey for the audience keeping with the story to get there. I know some reviews say the movie is true to the books and even some people behind me said "that was so good!" So maybe I just don't like the story. You'll have to decide for yourself.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: So the only reason i am writing this review is because most reviews here are BS !It was true to the book the songs where perfect if you're smart enough to understand the lyrics , and thr acting was verry good aswel . I know its a hype to hate stuff without decent reasons for the last few years but its getting ridiculous even with great movies.This movie does a perfect job of showing us how, Snow became the hatefull man we know him as i even sympathize with him a little bit .It also shows us how the capitol got tricked in liking the anual hunger games and making it more of a show then just killing.On top of that there are alot of easter eggs/ refferences to the movies we already have , so watch the movie and dont listen to the BS negative reviews.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I never read the book but I heard the movie adaptation is very close. If that's the case, the book must be incredibly boring. I'll admit the cinematography was great and it looked good. But the acting of a lot of the characters was not great, the purpose of the sister and grandma was 1000% missing - they might've well not been in the story at all, and after the actual games, you'd think Lucy Gray would be traumatized and have a hard time going back to her life. Nope! Not at all. This film was basically two films - the half before the games at the capital, and the half after they got to District 12. There was no connection in the two halves. BUT THE MOST ANNOYING PART: the main character NEVER PICKED A SIDE. It was impossible to pick apart his M. O., he got upset over things he caused and knew would happen ("uh oh, if it isn't the consequences to my own actions"), any character change happened offscreen, and he gave us no reason to root for him. I would've loved to see a slow burn to the crazed, evil Snow that we know from the trilogy. But there was no inciting incident that caused that. Also, Lucy Gray's actress has a beautiful voice, but there was too much singing in the movie, it was awkward, and didn't seem realistic at all.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This movie, about Coriolanus Snow who mentors and develops feelings for the female District 12 tribute during the 10th Hunger Games, is a great prequel to The Hunger Games (2012)!There's not a lot that needs to be said because there's only a few flaws, I think. One thing that I think is both a drawback and a great achievement at the same time is the character development, which is basically the main plot of the movie. I honestly think the series' original antagonist's psychological development from being "good" to "bad" may feel a bit too short for a single movie to be, but at the same time it's well executed for the 2 hours and 37 minutes it's been given. It can feel slightly rushed in therms of the big picture, but the scenes themselves that focus on Coriolanus' development is captivating, I think.Otherwise, I think the script is well written, the characters are interesting, Tom Blyth (as Coriolanus Snow) is the perfect cast for the protagonist, Coriolanus, most of the other actors also give good performances with especially Rachel Zegler's (as Lucy Gray Baird) beautiful voice, the cinematography is fantastic despite that I usually don't like wide angles, the scenery and costumes are gorgeous, and of course the score is beautiful as always. So overall, the movie is a worthy installment of The Hunger Games Pentalogy (2012-2023)!This is a captivating prequel that effectively delves into the origins of President Snow, despite the slightly rushed character development. The movie's strong script, compelling characters, and stunning visuals make it a worthy addition to The Hunger Games Pentalogy.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'm glad that Lucy Grey was a very different character than Katnis. It was a fantastic movie. Took us straight back to that awful, hash place and Snow was incredible. I can't imagine it was easy playing a complex changing character like young Snow. So we'll made & got the atmosphere spot on. I can't understand the negative reviews. Honestly baffled! Not sure why this website makes us get a 600 word review when half is more than enough. Not sure really what else I can say. It was fantastic and will definitely be buying film & keeping with the other Hunger games. This film really didn't let the franchise or books down.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Ballad of Songbirds preludes the original series, mostly focusing on hw Snow came to be. Its the tenth Hunger Games, and people had enough of the games. No one is watching AND a group of elite students are forced to join forces with the Hunger Games participants to get a coveted scholarship AND make changes to improve the games. A young Snow meets a young district 12 tribute and develop a relationship which would force them to reckon what each other truly loves first.There somethings special about this film that works wonderfully.In the world of quick Marvel thrill, this slow burn epic character study has lost its way in the screen. There is stakes there is real difference in agenda AND I like that. I think the original series has this grand scheme that does work well since its message is clear BUT this film feels much more pointed. The violence here feels wretched compared to the original. It is inherently darker and hopeless. The lack of technology makes things much less surreal than the original.Snow here, is almost similar to what he'll be in the future BUT he still has this sort of finding his footing. His pragmatic and knows his limitation. He is priviledged enough to study in a prestigious school but is not rich enough to really go for broke with his ideas. He is still beneath most of them. When given a chance to find a way to get a scholarship he clearly needs, he step forward AND find himself too entangled. He develops a selffish love for someone who truly wants to live and win BUT whose heart lays close to her home.I know there is a clear criticism that can be laid on some parts of the film. The third act does swerve pace wise, and feels almost like a seperate story that felt too rushed. While I do not consider it as bad per se, but I feel that there are ways to continue the stakes of the first 2/3 of the film AND improve the overall . The singing too can be bothersome and does feel Glee TV-like.Otherwise, big kudos to Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler. They really made the film. The film is not perfect but they are able to perfectly encapsulate the moods the shifts of the film. Its definitely not cookie cutter stuff. Though, Josh Andres Rivera was not fit to do the heavy lifting to show the needed conflict in the latter part of the film. I LOVE ZANY VIOLA DAVIS and JASON SCHWARTZMANN. I like when they camps it up but not so much.Highly recommended. Probably one of the better big budget films in the longest while. BUT I do feel this needs a BASIC knowledge of the Hunger Games Series.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I think it stayed as true to the book as the length of the movie would allow. There had to be a lot of adapting to fit 500+ pages in a 2.5 hour movie.That being said, I don't think they did a great job of conveying Snow's internal struggle. Love vs His Future. Human Decency vs Power. His Past vs His Present. He was CONSTANTLY torn in the book.Throughout the book, you wondered how he would eventually turn "bad". His journey and eventual decision makes sense and doesn't seem quick and sudden. There doesn't seem to be an obvious character arc in the movie that shows his change.At the end of the movie, Snow's "betrayal" and reaction towards Lucy may seem confusing and rushed if you don't have background from reading the book. You don't really know how much Lucy means to him and how shocking that ending should be.It's a good adaptation, but it's definitely not the best Hunger Games movie!

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: While I didn't read the book, and origin stories aren't typically my thing, this movie managed to strike a chord with me, largely thanks to the heartfelt performances of Tom Blyth and Rachel Zegler as Coriolanus Snow and Lucy Gray Baird. Blyth nailed the portrayal of a young Snow, adding layers to the character, while Zegler's was rapturous as Baird.Despite the commendable performances, the storyline lacked the depth needed for a more fulfilling experience. As a result, while I appreciate the leads for making the movie memorizing, I can't shake the feeling that the overall story could have been more robust. Hence, my rating stands at a 7.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games remains an entertaining and thought-provoking cinematic experience. It successfully introduces audiences to a captivating world, but the film's occasional missteps prevent it from reaching its full potential. With a tighter focus on character development and pacing, the movie could have been more compelling.I see immense, giant, tremendous potential in this series. I'll always watch the films in anticipation of more and more. If you're someone with high expectations, lower them. I just hope that in the future, the upcoming movies are more profound, impactful, and different. Perhaps with a better soundtrack that reflects the vastness, depth, and ultimately the dystopian world in which the story unfolds.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Laughing until we pass out. Similar to "Harry Potter," the book series whose popularity in Hollywood allowed for the creation of this franchise, the big-screen adaptations made several mistakes before finding success with a single filmmaker, who is now back to helm a prequel that remarkably expands the canon while adhering to its basic ideas."The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" strikes a balance between political commentary at a level appropriate for young viewers while also honoring blood sport and young love, as only Collins can. It feels like a logical continuation of the narrative. Her message is more about identifying how institutions use entertainment to divert attention from and control the masses than it is about opposing fascism. Collins does, however, allow a soulful folk singer-the title's figurative songbird-to act as the voice of resistance even inside that critique.Rachel Zegler, the star of "West Side Story," pays grudging homage to Lucy Gray Baird. She is a hybrid of Jennifer Lawrence's selfless hero Katniss Everdeen from the original films, Victor Hugo's enthralling Gypsy Esmeralda, and a pop icon like Taylor Swift who unites people. Her songs are the high point of a gloomy thriller that is overly drawn out by thirty minutes and becomes incredibly confusing towards the end. However, Hollywood has long since concluded that people enjoy their blockbusters obese, and "Ballad" is just the most recent example of over-delivering.There's just one character in "Ballad" that viewers will recognize immediately: Coriolanus Snow, the future dictator (played by Donald Sutherland), who is now an underdog cadet. This implies that, similar to "Cruella," "Wicked," and "Maleficent," the main character in the movie is a villain who was once youthful, desperate, and... attractive.
